contacts.name: Rhea Pierre
contacts.title: Technical Officer – Evolving Crisis and Disasters

field_reports.description:
Event Overview: Tropical Storm Rafael (previously Depression 18) passed near Jamaica between November 4-5, 2024, triggering nationwide weather warnings and flooding concerns.

Timeline and Impact:

  • Nov 4, 5:00 PM: System strengthened to Tropical Storm Rafael, approaching Jamaica from the south
  • Heavy rainfall and thunderstorms affected multiple parishes
  • Nov 5, 8:00 AM: Storm began strengthening while moving away from Jamaica
  • Nov 5, 2:00 PM: Tropical Storm Warning discontinued

Current Situation:

  • Flash Flood Warning remains in effect for southern parishes:
    • Westmoreland, St. Elizabeth, Manchester, Clarendon
    • St. Catherine, Kingston, St. Andrew, St. Thomas
  • Flash Flood Watch in effect for northern parishes:
    • Hanover, St. James, Trelawny
    • St. Ann, St. Mary, Portland

The situation has transitioned from a tropical storm threat to a flooding concern, particularly in the island's southern region.

contacts.name: Rhea  Pierre
contacts.title: Technical Officer – Evolving Crisis and Disasters

field_reports.description:
As of 5:00pm November 3, 2024, a Tropical Storm Warning has been issued for Jamaica. At 4:00pm on November 3, 2024, the potential tropical cyclone 18 was located 600 kilometers southwest of Negril Point and is moving towards the northeast. Maximum sustained winds are near 55km/h with higher gusts. This system is expected to become a tropical depression in the night and is expected strengthen steadily. 

This potential tropical cyclone 18 is expected to continue moving towards Jamaica and should be near Jamaica by late Monday evening. While this system is in the vicinity of Jamaica, it is expected to produce locally heavy rainfall and strong gusty winds, primarily over eastern and southern parishes on Monday and Tuesday. Landslides should also be anticipated. 

All small craft operators including fishers from the cays and banks should return to the mainland and start preparations for safe harbour. 
 
As at 8:00am on Monday, November 4, 2024, a bulletin issued by the Meteorological Office of Jamaica Service states that the potential Tropical Cyclone 18 is forecasted to strengthen into a Tropical Depression during the day. As a result, tropical storm conditions will begin to affect Jamaica within the next 24 hours.

countries.society_name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Red Cross
countries.name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

contacts.name: Rhea Pierre
contacts.title: Acting Technical Lead - Disaster Risk Management

field_reports.description: As of Wednesday, July 3, 2024, the coastal sections of eastern parishes started to experience strong winds and surges. The eyewall of Hurricane Beryl moved just off the south coast of Jamaica, bringing heavy rains, storms surges, and flooding in some areas. The parishes most affected are Clarendon, Manchester and St. Elizabeth with small sections of other parishes recieving damage mainly from the winds. Approximately 1,000 persons occupied over 190 shelters  across the island. There are a number of persons who lost the roofs to their homes, however a final count is not available at this point. The agricultural sector was also affected.

contacts.name: Rhea Pierre
contacts.title: Acting Technical Lead - Disaster Risk Management

field_reports.description: As of July 1, 2024 at 8:00pm, a hurricane warning was issued for Jamaica as Hurricane Beryl enters into the Caribbean. Hurricane Beryl is currently at a category with maximum sustained of 165/mph, with expected fluctuations in strength and direction. There are several communities across the island that are expected to be impacted by strong winds, storm surge and floods as indicated by Office of Disaster Preparedness and Emergency Management (ODPEM). Electricity and water supply will be disrupted during and after the passage of Beryl as communicated by these service providers (Jamaica Public Service & National Water Commission)

contacts.name: Rhea Pierre
contacts.title: Technical Officer - Evolving Crisis and Disasters

field_reports.description:
At 5:00 am June 30, 2024, the center of Hurricane Beryl was located near latitude 10.7 North, longitude 53.1 West, about 500 nautical miles east-southeast of Grenada. Beryl is expected to move across the Windward islands early on Monday. Currently, maximum sustained winds have increased to 100mph and rapid strengthening is forecasted. Information from the Meterological Services and NADMA advises that Grenada can expect to experience Hurricane conditions from Sunday evening in to Monday. The Northern part of the island (St, Patrick, St. Andrew, St. Mark, Carriacou and Petite Martinique) may be more severely affected. As such, subsequent to an emergency meeting held last evening of the National Emergency Advisory Council (NEAC), the following decisions were taken: 1) Emergency Shelters, district emergency operations centers and the National Emergency Operations Center will be activated from 12 noon on Sunday June 30, 2024 2) There is a scheduled water turn off from 9PM on Sunday 3) It is unlikely that there will be school on Monday as most schools are being used as hurricane shelters 4) Once the NEOC is activated at noon, there should be updates every 3 hours

UPDATE - JULY 1, 2024 - 6:45AM

Grenada is currently experiencing the effects of the outer bands from Hurricane Beryl. There are reports of rainfall, thunder, lightening and some high seas (varying degrees), however, no loss or damages reported thus far. Advisory from the Grenada Met Office relays that the hurricane is now located approximately 125 miles, 200KM ESE of Grenada with a 20 MPH speed. The effects is expected to intensify between the hours of 8AM and 8PM.

Last evening at 7PM the EOC was activated and a state of emergency was declared by the Government of Grenada (to be in effect for 7 days in the first instance unless otherwise advised). The team was at the EOC overnight monitoring the situation. Additionally, since the opening of the shelters approximately 2500 persons relocated to them across the tri-island state. Teams are assigned to these shelters, reports of 2 minor health related issues and blankets and other sleeping gears provided.

 

UPDATE - JULY 2, 2024 12:29PM

The tri-island state of Grenada, Carriacou and Petite Martinique was hit by category 4 Hurricane Beryl on July 1, 2024. Effects were felt from as early as 7AM and lasted throughout the day at different parts of the island. Hurricane force winds ravaged the North of Grenada along with the islands of Carriacou & Petite Martinique. Initial reports show widespread destruction with some houses completed damaged while others loss their roofs. The all-clear was given as of 8PM on July 1, however, the country remains under a state of emergency.

countries.society_name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Red Cross
countries.name: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

field_reports.description:
Hurricane Beryl poses significant risks and potential impacts to the Caribbean islands, particularly affecting St. Vincent and the Grenadines (SVG).   It is moving towards the west at 22mph (35km/h) with an increased maximum sustained winds of 80mph (130 km/h).  Hurricane  force  winds  extend  outward  up  to  10  miles  (20  km)  from  the  center,  and  tropical storm force winds extend outward up to 60 miles (95km). The effects of the winds could be felt from Sunday night.  Maximum sustained winds of 80 - 110 mph (129 – 177 km/h) or greater are expected across St. Vincent and the Grenadines, with possible higher winds offshore.   Rainfall accumulations of 4 to 6 inches (100 to 150mm) are likely across St. Vincent and the Grenadines.   Marine  conditions  are  expected  to  be  very  rough  and  hazardous  with  sea-swells  exceeding 4.0m (13ft) and possibly higher ~8.0m (26ft), near the center of ‘Beryl’ during Monday. Storm surges are possible across SVG.  Large and destructive waves/swells are likely to cause life-threatening surf and rip currents.   The government of St Vincent and the Grenadines has urged everyone to be prepared by putting together emergency supplies; shelters are to be activated by 6 p.m. and the NEOC activated at 8 p.m. on Sunday 30th June, 2024. The SVGRC continues to provide support  by continuously sharing updates on the weather and organizing volunteers to support shelter operations. In addition, volunteers were conducting walk through in their various communities, checking the vulnerable population and assisting families with preparation for the impending event.

Update: As at 12:00 p,m. on June 30, 2024, Hurricane Beryl has since intensified to a category four (4) hurricane with no change in its directed path. It is currently located at 260 mile ESE of St. Vincent and the Grenadines with the eye of the hurricane projected to pass between Grenada and the Grenadine Islands.  The hurricane force winds will extend up to 30 miles from the eye and the storm force winds will extend up to 115 miles. The populace of St. Vincent and the Grenadines will begin to feel the effects of the hurricane from midnight.  There are currently 817 persons in 34 shelters across St. Vincent and the Grenadines.

contacts.name: Rhea Pierre
contacts.title: Acting Emergency Focal Point and Technical Lead – Evolving Crisis and Disasters

field_reports.other_affected_pop_centres: St. Philip, Christ Church, St. John, St. Joseph, St. Andrew, St. Peter, St. Lucy
field_reports.description: On the current projected track, the center of Beryl is expected to pass 45 km (26 miles) south of Barbados. The island is expected to feel the impacts associated with this system as early as late Sunday night, June 30, 2024. It is anticipated that the passage of Tropical Storm Beryl will bring strong winds that could cause damage to homes and properties. Additionally, flash flooding is likely across the island especially in flood-prone areas and severe thunderstorm activity may cause multiple interruptions to power utilities and services. It is anticipated that marine conditions will be hazardous ahead of and during the passage of Beryl. Tropical Storm Beryl has continued to strengthen and at 8am (Saturday 29th June, 2024) the system was located near 9.8N 46.8W or about 1570km (975 miles) east-southeast of Barbados. Some of the more densely populated parishes are likely to be directly impacted (St. Philip, Christ Church, St. Michael); as well as parishes that are particularly prone to flooding, tsunami threats and land slippage (St. Peter, St. Andrew, St. John and St. Joseph)

results.summary:
Since June 25, the National Hurricane Center began monitoring a tropical wave with the potential for development that was moving westward. By June 28, already transformed into Tropical Depression 2 / system AL95, it began to intensify due to atmospheric conditions and officially became Tropical Storm Beryl. 

The final conditions to become a hurricane happened on June 29, becoming the first major hurricane of the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season and the earliest category 4 hurricane to form in recorded history, on June 30. By July 1st it would become a category 5 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 270 kmh.
results.name: Hurricane Beryl - Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada, Barbados and Jamaica

field_reports.summary: JAM: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 11-2023 - Potential Tropical Cyclone #22 #2 (2023-11-17)
field_reports.description:
As of 5:00pm on November 16, 2023, a tropical storm watch and flash flood warning was issued for Jamaica given the development of the low pressure system. Flash flood watch was upgraded to a flash flood warning for low-lying and flood prone areas od southern and eastern parishes of Westmoreland, St. Elizabeth, Manchester, Clarendon, St. Catherine, Kingston, St. Andrew, St. Thomas, Portland and St. Mary. The flash food watch remains in effect for the other parishes of Hanover, St. James, Trelawny, St. James and st. Ann. 

On November 17, flooding, landslides and blocked roadways due to fallen trees have been reported in several parishes as outlined below: 

  1. St. Catherine - Flooding and blocked roadways including the closure of Bog Walk Gorge. Minor landslides reported
  2. St. Thomas - Flooding and blocked roadways. Approx. 22 persons were stranded. 
  3. Kingston - Flooding and blocked roadways 
  4. St. Andrew - Landslides reported
  5. Portland - Blocked roadways due to fallen trees and utility poles. 
  6. Clarendon - flooding reported

field_reports.summary: JAM: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 11-2023 - Broad Low Pressure System
field_reports.description: On Monday, November 13, 2023, the National Meteorological Service issued a severe weather alert for Jamaica, prompted by a disturbance in the southwestern Caribbean region with the potential to evolve into a tropical depression or tropical storm within the next seven days. This system has the potential to impact Jamaica. Subsequently, on Thursday, November 16, 2023, a flash flood watch was issued for low-lying and flood-prone areas across all parishes. This flash flood watch will remain in effect until 8:00 am on Friday, November 17, 2023. While certain roadways have been inundated, no significant adverse impacts have been reported thus far.

results.summary: On Monday, November 13, 2023, the National Meteorological Service issued a severe weather alert for Jamaica, prompted by a disturbance in the southwestern Caribbean region with the potential to evolve into a tropical depression or tropical storm within the next seven days. This system has the potential to impact Jamaica. Subsequently, on Thursday, November 16, 2023, a flash flood watch was issued for low-lying and flood-prone areas across all parishes. This flash flood watch will remain in effect until 8:00 am on Friday, November 17, 2023. While certain roadways have been inundated, no significant adverse impacts have been reported thus far.
results.name: JAM: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 11-2023 - Broad Low Pressure System

field_reports.description: The Government of Jamaica on September 23, 2023 declared a national outnreak of Dengue Fever outbreak with 565 suspected, presumed and confirmed cases of Dengue. Of that number, 78 cases had been confirmed with majority of the cases seen in Kingston & St. Andrew, St. Catherine and St. Thomas. The dominant strain is Dengue Type 2, which last predominated in 2010. There are no Dengue-related deaths classified at this time, however, six deaths are being investigated.

field_reports.summary: JAM: Population Movement - 2023-07 - Haitian Migrants arrival in Jamaica
field_reports.description:
The Jamaica Red Cross was advised by the Government of Jamaica of the arrival of 38 Haitian Nationals, who landed at Boston Bay in the parish of Portland, yesterday, Monday July 10, 2023. The 38 migrants are made up of 29 males and 9 females and of that number 9 are children (5 boys and 4 girls). The Haitians were later transferred from Portland to the Parish of St Mary, where they are currently being housed in a facility owned by the Seventh Day Adventist Church. 

The Jamaica Red Cross received information from the ODPEM that te migrants would be in Jamaica until the last weekend in July, however the Passport Immigration and Citizenship Agency advised the NS yerterday July 17th that the Government is seeking to have the migrants repatraited by Sunday July 23.

The Haitians were taken to Court today July 18th and we are awaitin the outcome.

field_reports.summary: BLZ: Cyclone - 2022-11 - Go report: Tropical Storm Lisa  #12 (2023-01-28)
field_reports.description: On November 2nd, Belize was faced with strong winds, heavy rains and flooding resulting from Tropical storm Lisa (Category one), 10 miles of Belize City. Major damages were caused in the Belize district with Belize City being severely impacted. Fortunately there were no deaths, however there was damage to infrastructure, roads and livestock.

Hurricane Lisa made landfall on 2nd November 2022 as a strong Category 1 storm, ten (10) miles south of Belize City at the mouth of the Sibun River in the Belize District. The storm caused major damage to the Belize District, with Belize City extensively impacted. Over 200 homes were destroyed, more than 300 structures suffered lost and/or damaged roofs, several local communities flooded, buildings, road networks and utilities infrastructure extensively damaged and some communities left inaccessible.

The Belize City Council confirms that the clean-up of the city has been completed and all debris left behind in the aftermath of Hurricane Lisa has been fully cleared. All schools have reopened. Those with additional needs stemming from damage resulting from the storm continue to receive assistance from the Government. Schools are operating at almost full capacity.

The NEMO and CEMO officials have concluded DANA (Disaster Assessment and Needs Analysis) in affected areas and have delivered relief supplies where necessary. The government had indicated that only the Standard Bearers (Area Representatives) would be on the ground providing relief. The BRC continues to liaise with NEMO and CEMO to coordinate assistance and provide support to their relief efforts by delivering aid to areas not yet covered by the agencies.

The Government this week announced that further to the DANA conducted by Government agencies, UNDP will be providing additional technical support in the form of new assessments that include the components of social and economic parameters.

Utility works are still ongoing, the national grid remains operational at 99%. BEL continues to their works on the George Price Highway and the Belize River Valley in repairing and replacing leaning electricity poles.

The BWS distribution system countrywide remains fully functional since the post-storm repairs and restoration work.

Local cable and broadband providers have reported they have completed all restoration works to their systems and have now resumed general service works and installations within the city.

The Government’s estimates that storm damages assessed to date, total BZ$250million, and that figure is on the rise.

The Government of Belize continues to receive support for Hurricane Lisa relief efforts, both monetary donations and in-kind contributions.

The Government of South Korea donated BZ$300,000 to complement the Government of Belize’s ongoing hurricane assistance to the most vulnerable families affected by the storm. The Direct Cash Transfer programme is facilitated through the Ministry of Human Development.

Hurricane Lisa made landfall on 2nd November 2022 as a strong Category 1 storm, ten (10) miles south of Belize City at the mouth of the Sibun River in the Belize District. The storm caused major damage to the Belize District, with Belize City extensively impacted. Over 200 homes were destroyed, more than 300 structures suffered lost and/or damaged roofs, several local communities flooded, buildings, road networks and utilities infrastructure extensively damaged and some communities left inaccessible.

Hurricane Lisa made landfall on 2nd November 2022 as a strong Category 1 storm, ten (10) miles south of Belize City at the mouth of the Sibun River in the Belize District. The storm caused major damage to the Belize District, with Belize City extensively impacted. Over 200 homes were destroyed, more than 300 structures suffered lost and/or damaged roofs, several local communities flooded, buildings, road networks and utilities infrastructure extensively damaged and some communities left inaccessible.

Hurricane Lisa made landfall on 2nd November 2022 as a strong Category 1 storm, ten (10) miles south of Belize City at the mouth of the Sibun River in the Belize District. The storm caused major damage to the Belize District, with Belize City extensively impacted. Over 200 homes were destroyed, more than 300 structures suffered lost and/or damaged roofs, several local communities flooded, buildings, road networks and utilities infrastructure extensively damaged and some communities left inaccessible.

Hurricane Lisa made landfall on 2nd November 2022 as a strong Category 1 storm ten (10) miles south of Belize City at the mouth of the Sibun River in the Belize District. The storm caused major damage to the Belize District, with Belize City extensively damaged. With over 200 homes destroyed, over 300 structures suffered lost and/or damaged roofs, several local communities flooded, buildings, road networks and utilities infrastructure extensively damaged and some communities left inaccessible.

The cleanup continues across the entire city in public spaces, residential and commercial areas and in the few remaining schools that are still unable to fully recover from the storm damage and utilities loss. Most schools have now returned to in-person classes.

The Belize City Council continues to be aided in their efforts by other government agencies, charity organizations, private businesses, and citizens. The national water company, BWS, continues to assist the Belize City council with cleanup operations by facilitating the movement of debris with heavy machinery.  The city council reported that to date thirty-five (35) tons of debris were removed from the city following the passing of the storm.

The NEMO and CEMO officials remain active, both in conducting DANA (Disaster Assessment and Needs Analysis) outreach in affected areas and delivering relief. The BRC continues to liaise with NEMO and CEMO to coordinate assistance and provide support to their relief efforts by delivering aid to areas not yet covered by the agencies.

Utility works are still ongoing, the national grid remains operational at 99%. BEL continues to their works on the George Price Highway and the Belize River Valley in repairing and replacing leaning and fallen electricity poles.

The BWS distribution system countrywide remains fully functional since the post-storm repairs and restoration work, only a few customers remain without water.

Customers that remain without utility (electricity & water) services are due primarily to damaged services lines and meters caused by the storm, which are usually individual service entrance points to private property and often required a private electrician at the cost of the customer.

field_reports.other_affected_pop_centres: Belize, Toledo, Stann Creek, Cayo Districts
field_reports.description: LAST UPDATE FROM NEMO: they have activated early warning protocols and the EOC. A hurricane warning (Red II) has been declared for the entire coast of Belize. A flash flood warning is in effect. Shelters are available countrywide including Belize City. Key partners including the BRC have been meeting and supporting each other. Residents are advised to continue monitoring this system very closely and to follow official information coming from NEMO and the National Met Service NEMO’s has activated emergency evacuation with the BDF and an emergency hotline is 936. Situational reports from volunteers indicate that many communities countrywide are being affected by hurricane Lisa. Many homes have been destroyed and people are in need of shelter and assistance. NEMO has activated shelters and search and rescue but the influx of calls has been overwhelming, shelters are crowded and the current situation is risk to deploy first responders. Phone towers have also been down and the lost of electricity has made it difficult for people to access life-saving rescue. The storm has passed over the Belize district and is now moving over the Cayo District but rains and flooding is still affecting majority of the country.

field_reports.gov_affected_pop_centres: Belize District, Toledo District, Stann Creek District
field_reports.description: The wall of the eye is already affecting the country. The National Meteorological Service of Belize (NMS) informed the public that at 12 midday that Hurricane Lisa was located near latitude 17.3N, longitude 87.7W or about 35 miles East-Southeast of Belize City. Lisa was moving to the west at 14 mph with maximum sustained winds of 80 mph and minimum central pressure of 987 mb. Lisa will continue on a general westward track today she is in the process of making landfall. Lisa is expected to maintain its current intensity or strengthen just a bit more before it makes landfall on the coast of Belize between Dangriga and Belize City. Heavy rainfall from this system has already started to affect the country and that will continue for the remainder of today through to Thursday with amounts of 4-6 inches and locally higher values of up to 8-12 inches. This will result in flooding across low-lying and flood-prone areas of the country and flash flooding especially over the south. Winds of upper category 1 hurricane strength of 80-90 mph with a storm surge of 4-7 feet to the north of where the center makes landfall. Strong gusty winds will result in very rough sea conditions with large battering waves. A state of emergency has be declared for the Belize and Stann Creek districts from 3:00 p.m. today until the "All Clear" is given. A curfew will go into effect from dusk today until dawn on Thursday, 3rd November 2022. Only emergency and security agencies are allowed to be on the roads and streets during this period. Volunteers report roofs, trees, and power lines have already become hazards in some communities as the storm makes its way over the country. Many communities have been experiencing flooding from the outer bands of the hurricane. Media houses are reporting heavy rainfall, winds, and flooding in various parts of the country.

field_reports.gov_affected_pop_centres: Belize District, Stann Creek District, Toledo District
field_reports.description: Hurricane Lisa is expected to make landfall within a couple of hours. The National Meteorological Service of Belize and the National Emergency Management Organization informs the general public that at 7:00 p.m. (local time) Hurricane Lisa was located near latitude 16.7N, longitude 84.0W or about 285 miles east of Belize City. Lisa was moving to the west at 15 mph with maximum sustained winds of 65 mph and minimum central pressure of 996 mb. This system will bring heavy rainfall with amounts of 4-6 inches and locally higher values of up to 8-12 inches starting on Wednesday and continuing through Thursday, which will result in flooding across low-lying and flood prone areas of the country and flash flooding especially over the south. Winds of upper category 1 hurricane strength of 90-95 mph or category 2 strength of 96 -110 mph are expected near the landfall location with a storm surge of 4-7 feet to the north of where the centre makes landfall. Strong gusty winds will result in very rough sea conditions with large battering waves.

field_reports.other_affected_pop_centres: Belize District, Stann Creek District, Toledo District
field_reports.description: The Chief Met officer’s report on Tropical Storm Lisa is as follows: The system is forecasted to become at least a category 1 hurricane before landfall on Belize late Wednesday evening into Wednesday night. The country is expecting 3 - 5 inches of rainfall with local higher values of about 8 to 12 inches as Lisa moves across the country. The system will make landfall over southern Belize near Dangriga, later in the night on Wednesday. A storm surge of about 3 to 5 feet is expected. This system is expected to come in with sustained winds of 80 miles per hour at the moment.

field_reports.other_affected_pop_centres: Toledo District, Stann Creek District, Belize District
field_reports.description: The National Meteorological Service of Belize and the National Emergency Management Organization (NEMO) informed the public that as at 6:30 pm Belize is under a hurricane watch. Tropical Storm Lisa was located near latitude 15.5N, longitude 78.9W or about 630 miles East-Southeast of Belize City. Lisa was moving to the west at 14 mph with maximum sustained winds of 45 mph and minimum central pressure of 1002 mb. Lisa is to continue on a general west to west-north-westward track for the next few days. On this forecasted track, the centre will pass south of Jamaica tonight, south of the Cayman Islands on Tuesday, then move near or over the Bay Islands of Honduras early on Wednesday, and approach Belize later on Wednesday. Strengthening is expected and Lisa is expected to be a category 1 hurricane by landfall on Wednesday evening. This system will bring heavy rainfall with amounts of 3-5 inches and locally higher values of up to 8 inches starting on Wednesday and continuing through Thursday, which will result in flooding across low-lying and flood-prone areas of the country. Winds of category 1 hurricane strength at 74-95 mph are expected near the landfall location with a storm surge of 3-5 feet to the north of where the centre makes landfall. Wind effect is likely to be felt throughout most areas of the country.

field_reports.other_affected_pop_centres: Belize City, Toledo District, Stann Creek District
field_reports.description: Cheif Met Officer updated NEMO with the following: comparing the European model versus the American GFS model. Both show the system affecting Belize. However, the Euro has it making landfall on Wednesday evening as a weak tropical storm or tropical depression. The GFS has it making landfall over southern Belize on Thursday morning as a strong tropical storm or even a minor hurricane. It is likely to have a landfalling system but exact timing and intensity is still not too certain. System will likely produce heavy rainfall late Wednesday and Thursday with about 2 to 4 inches per day with locally higher amounts.

results.summary:
The direct impact of Hurricane Lisa comes just 2 weeks after the country experienced heavy rains and associated flooding following the passage of Tropical Storm Julia. According to NEMO, flooding as a result of tropical storm Julia affected roughly 30 communities in southern and central Belize and approximately 3,000 families had been directly or indirectly impacted.

In 2020, flooding associated with the passage of Hurricanes Eta and Iota cut off several communities, with Cayo, Stann Creek, and Belize districts being most affected. Approximately 15% of the total population in Belize was impacted. In response to these historic floods, the Belize Red Cross launched a DREF operation that targeted 5,000 people. The operation supported the distribution of household items, WASH activities and multi-purpose cash Page 3 / 18 assistance.

It should be noted that the recent impacts outlined above were not the result of a direct impact of a hydro meteorological hazard. However, hurricane Lisa directly impacted Belize and so the scale of impact can be reasonably expected to exceed these 2 previous events. Belize Red Cross (BRC) has received reports through staff, volunteers, and the National Emergency Management Office (NEMO) that several communities have been affected. Major areas impacted (hardest hit) are communities in Belize, Stann Creek and Toledo Districts as forecasted by the NEMO and Meteorological services. However there has also been some significant impacts in Cayo and Orange Districts.

Initial close estimates indicate overall 333,549 people in the country were at risk from impacts from the system. According to NEMO, at least 39% of the total population of Belize (approximately 160,000 people) was most affected by Hurricane Lisa. Only in the district of Belize, more than 90,000 people are reported to have been impacted. Among the effects, substantial damage has been reported to property. It is estimated that approximately 500 houses have been completely destroyed, while more than 5,000 houses have been partially destroyed in the Belize District. Partial damage ranged from roofs being blown off, structures being partially destroyed, ground floors being flooded and household goods being destroyed by wind and water. Initial estimates of losses to the housing sector amounts to some BZD 20 million (Approximately USD 10 million).

The Relief Supplies and Management Subcommittee of the National Emergency Management Organization (NEMO) has indicated the need to provide immediate relief to some estimated 5,000 plus families in the Belize District, and up to 1,000 families in the Stann Creek District. The estimated number of families affected in the Cayo, Orange Walk and Corozal districts can reach as much as 500 families.

Food, water, hygiene kits, bedding, cleaning supplies, tarpaulins, buckets, PPEs, power washers, construction and roofing material are the main items needed for the affected population. In addition, further damage and needs assessments (DANA) will be conducted to ensure the most appropriate provision support of affected population. Multi-Purpose Cash will be utilized as a modality for provision of support to ensure dignity, freedom of choice and facilitate livelihood reactivation where markets/business can accommodate.
results.name: BELIZE: Tropical Storm Lisa

field_reports.description:
Jamaica has been placed under a Tropical Storm Watch as of Friday, September 23,2022.The weather conditions for Jamaica is expected to deteriorate with rainfall and heavy winds from the outer bands of the Tropical Storm starting from Saturday, September 24, 2022 going into Sunday September 25, 2022. The center of the storm should pass South West of Jamaica. 

The western parishes are expected to be most affected by the heavy rains. However, other low-lying flood prone areas may be affected by the outer bands of the Tropical Storm. Small craft operators and fishers from the cays and banks have been urged to move inland take the necessary precautionary measures to secure themselves and equipment.

results.summary:
Jamaica has been placed under a Tropical Storm Watch as of Friday, September 23,2022.The weather conditions for Jamaica is expected to deteriorate with rainfall and heavy winds from the outer bands of the Tropical Storm starting from Saturday, September 24, 2022 going into Sunday September 25, 2022. The center of the storm should pass South West of Jamaica. 

The western parishes are expected to be most affected by the heavy rains. However, other low-lying flood prone areas may be affected by the outer bands of the Tropical Storm. Small craft operators and fishers from the cays and banks have been urged to move inland take the necessary precautionary measures to secure themselves and equipment.
results.name: JAM: Flood - 2022-09 - Tropical Storm Ian

field_reports.description: The floods caused by a severe weather event affected the parishes of Portland, st. Ann and St. Mary. Since the event, the waters have receded leaving debris and blocked roads that have since been cleared by NWA or community efforts. Some areas were without electricity as a result of downed trees on power lines. Damage Assessments and Needs Analyses are being conducted in the affected areas and relief supplies are being distributed where needed.

Flooding in the Northern Parishes has affected a number of persons including schools, farms, and residents living in these areas. There are reports of blocked roadways and loss of electricity in some areas due to fallen trees in the roadways. An area in St. Ann has been affected by a landslide which is compromising the dwelling of persons living in that area.

field_reports.summary: Jamaica: Tropical Wave to Tropical Storm Ida (2021-08-25)
field_reports.description:
The Tropical Wave started to bring adverse weather conditions associated with the system on Aug. 25 through to August 27. As a result, a Flash flood warning was put in effect for eastern and south-central parishes. On August 26, 2021, the Tropical Wave developed into a Tropical Storm southwest of Jamaica. As a result, a flash flood warning was put in place for all parishes. 
Tropical storm Ida caused severe flooding and landslides in several parishes such as Clarendon, Manchester, St. Ann, Westmoreland, St. Elizabeth, Hanover, Trelawny and Kingston & St. Andrew to a lesser extent . Several homes and communities were impacted causing some persons to relocate to the closest shelter .

results.name: Jamaica: Tropical Wave to Tropical Storm Ida (2021-08-25)

field_reports.description: Tropical Storm Grace has affected mainly eastern and central parishes so far with some areas experiencing heavy flooding and landslides in some areas. The high wind speeds that accompany TS Grace has caused trees to fall and block roads as well downed utility poles in some parishes listed above leaving some communities without electricity. Shelters have been activated in St. Mary, St Andrew and Clarendon.

The Meterological Service Jamaica lifts Tropical Storm Warning for Jamaica as Elsa continues to move further away towards Cuba. There is no longer a threat of Tropical Storm conditions. 
Government authorities are already forecasting significant damage to the island’s road infrastructure, with sections of Clarendon and St. Catherine appearing to have suffered the worst blows. 
Government authorities continue to work to clear blocked roads as best as possible in the affected areas Clarendon, Kingston & St. Andrew & St. Catherine.

As the tropical strorm warning remains in effect for the country, the NEOC was activated with representation from the Jamaica Red Cross. Also shelters have been activated to assist those that would be displaced as a result of the heavy rains caused by TS Elsa. The Parish Emergency Operating Centres have also been fully activated in most parishes (6) and partially activated in some (2) while (6) PEOCs were not activated however, representatives have been placed on standby.  
Response agencies have been actively engaged in the pre-positioning of resources and assets for emergency response. 
St. Mary, Portland, St. Thomas, Kingston & St. Andrew, St. Catherine and Clarendon are most at risk for flooding, storm surge, and landslides based on on risk exposure and historical impacts and projected path of Tropical Storm Elsa.

The cyclone affects these countries: Barbados, Trinidad and Tobago, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Martinique, Grenada, Dominica, Dominican Republic, Haiti, Cuba, United States, Jamaica (vulnerability High). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 0.

results.summary:
Context:

Tropical storm Elsa is now off the Florida Keys this morning and will move near or over portions of the west coast of Florida later today through tonight. It is expected to make landfall along the north Florida Gulf coast. El Centro de Pronósticos del Instituto de Meteorología, reports that Tropical Storm Elsa is moving away from Cuban territory and does not represent a danger for Cuba. All provinces that were on alert are to return to normality and to continue monitoring weather reports.

 

IFRC actions:

·       IFRC has been following up on Elsa since 28-June when it was forecasted to reach the Caribbean

·       Closely coordinating with the NSs of Barbados, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Grenada, Dominican Republic, Haiti, Jamaica and Cuba

·       A total of 6 information messages and 1 bulletin have been issued

·       1 JFT and multiple coordination meetings with the country cluster delegations in Port of Spain and Santo Domingo

·       Tropical Storm Monitoring Dashboard: https://go.ifrc.org/emergencies/5379#details

·       IFRC Disaster Managers (DMs) and Disaster Preparedness Coordinator attending daily meetings with the CDPG

·       The Regional Logistics Unit (RLU) has been closely monitoring and preparing for a possible response

·       Preparedness Dashboard https://go.ifrc.org/regions/1#additional-info

·       The Communications Team has been in contact with NSs, has shared key messages, press release templates and preparedness messages on social media

·       The Community engagement and accountability (CEA) team has been in contact with NSs, sharing and gathering Information. The CEA team also shared the Hurricane Preparedness CEA summary tools and follows up with NSs

·       IFRC will continue monitoring and following up with National Societies

 

Cuban Red Cross:

·       According to the information from the Forecasting Center of the Institute of Meteorology, Tropical Storm Elsa is moving away from the national territory and does not represent a danger for Cuba. Therefore, it was decided to return to normality in the provinces of Sancti Spíritus, Cienfuegos, Villa Clara, Matanzas, Mayabeque, Havana, Artemisa, Pinar del Rio and the Isla de la Juventud Special Municipality

·       The Ministry of Communications evaluated the damage to the communications system caused by tropical storm Elsa and so far no serious damage has been detected

·       No major damages have been reported in the country and the government is responding to the affectations

·       The NS volunteers and staff are on alert and assisting in the needs assessments

·       The governor of the province of Matanzas assured that in spite of the persistent rains of tropical storm Elsa, it did not cause significant damage in the territory. The abundance of rainfall, the overflowing of rivers and the runoff caused flooding in low-lying areas and forced the evacuation of hundreds of people, as happened in the La Marina neighbourhood in the provincial capital

·       In total, more than 2,000 people were evacuated in state-run centres in the province and some 20,000 people found protection in the homes of family and friends and will be receiving support from the government

·       More than 20 percent of the population was without electricity service, and by late morning the restitution of the service was advancing at an accelerated pace. The director of the Electricity Company said that some 42 areas were without electricity service, which affected some 84,000 customers. It has already been restored for 12,000. 95 percent of the service should be resolved this Tuesday
results.name: Tropical Storm Elsa Monitoring

field_reports.summary: Severe Weather Impacts on Jamaica from Tropical Storm Eta and possible impact from TS Iota
field_reports.description:
Jamaica has been facing severe impacts from several tropical systems over the last three months, which have resulted in significant rainfall induced flood events, land slippages, livelihood disruptions and severe infrastructural damage among other impacts in late October. However these impacts culminated with the passing of Tropical Storm Eta, which has caused widespread damage especially in the south, west and east of the Island, however the ODPEM has declared 8 of the 14 parishes vulnerable to flooding and these severe impacts. The situation was further compounded by previously significant ground saturation from consistent rainfall as well as previous impacts on infrastructure and on November 08, the country began experiencing the full brunt of the bands of TS Eta which according to the Government has brought the cost of damage to the Island's road network alone to Two Billion Jamaican Dollars (approximately 15 million USD), with several communities being marooned due to collapsed roadways, which has resulted in many being without food and other necessities. The Bull Bay area in St Andrew is one area that as been significantly impacted with many residents being displaced by debris flooding from the Chalky River, with any houses being damaged beyond repair or compromised beyond any further safe habitation, with the government discussing relocation programmes for these areas. A significant number of families have lost most of their physical possessions in he main areas impacted as a result of flooding and will need long term assistance.

Some families continue to abide in Public Shelters, while many have resorted to staying with family and friends. The need for food among persons in the impacted areas has been highlighted, with the government, the Jamaica Red Cross and other NGOs responding. With more rains forecasted in the coming days, the government has issued evacuation orders to persons in vulnerable areas.

results.name: Severe Weather Impacts on Jamaica from Tropical Storm Eta
